content.body: Chrome attempts to load the source map via the inspected page itself at first. So if the page fails to `fetch` the source map, so will Chrome DevTools
content.formatted_body: Chrome attempts to load the source map via the inspected page itself at first. So if the page fails to fetch the source map, so will Chrome DevTools

content.body: interesting. the error isn't of any use really ("unexpected error" or some such thing). but im guessing its a cross-origin thing then
in this case im also using devtools for node, so there is no 'page'. not sure what the rules are then, i.e. what is the origin etc
i imagine debug IDs will make this a lot easier one day if someone hosts a server to look them up ðŸ˜…

The problems that debug IDs are solving is distinguishing two different source maps that are hosted at the same URL (for example, because you updated your code and rebuild the source map). With the default devtools behavior, if you are already including the version of the file in the URL you are fetching then also having the ID is probably not super helpful.
content.formatted_body: The problems that debug IDs are solving is distinguishing two different source maps that are hosted at the same URL (for example, because you updated your code and rebuild the source map). With the default devtools behavior, if you are already including the version of the file in the URL you are fetching then also having the ID is probably not super helpful.

content.body: If Chrome devtools have problems fetching those source maps however, you might take a look at the extensions API mentioned in https://github.com/tc39/ecma426/issues/185
